TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON ( GPE ) . He is represented before the ORG by Mr J. GPE , a lawyer practising in GPE ( GPE ) .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant was involved in a road accident in which a passenger in his car was killed . Subsequently , criminal proceedings against the applicant were opened . On CARDINAL DATE ORG ) preferred a bill of indictment against the applicant charging him with having caused death by negligence in particularly dangerous conditions under LAW and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( fahrlässige PERSON besonders gefährlichen ORG ) , namely in a state of drunkenness .

On DATE ORG Bezirkshauptmannschaft ) summoned the applicant as he was suspected of having committed the administrative offence of driving a car in a state of drunkenness under LAW ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) of LAW ( Straßenverkehrsordnung ) .

On DATE the applicant admitted in his submissions to ORG that he had driven the car in a state of drunkenness , but stressed that ORG was not entitled to prosecute him for the administrative offence under LAW ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) of LAW , as criminal proceedings concerning the same issue were already pending . He relied on LAW .

On DATE and DATE the Ried Regional Court ( PERSON ) held hearings and , on the latter date , acquitted the applicant of the charges under LAW and QUANTITY as it had not been established that the applicant had caused the accident .
On DATE ORG issued a penal order ( PERSON ) against the applicant and fined him in the amount of ATS CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) for having driven a car in a state of drunkenness on DATE .
On DATE the applicant appealed relying on LAW No CARDINAL . He did not request a hearing .

On DATE ORG ( Unabhängiger Verwaltungssenat – hereafter referred to as ORG ) , sitting with a single member , dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It found that the present case had to be distinguished from the case of PERSON v. GPE ( judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL-C , pp . DATE , § § CARDINAL ) as the records of ORG hearings disclosed that the court , acquitting the applicant , had accepted his defence that the passenger killed in the accident had caused the accident by grabbing the steering wheel . As it could not be established that the applicant had caused the accident , ORG had not anymore been called upon to consider the further question whether the applicant had actually been drunk . Accordingly , ORG decision did not infringe the applicant ’s rights under LAW . CARDINAL .
On DATE the applicant filed a complaint with ORG ) . He submitted that the ORG ’s decision had been based on an unconstitutional provision and had violated his rights under LAW No CARDINAL .
On DATE the ORG submitted observations in reply and repeated in essence the arguments of its decision of DATE .

On DATE ORG quashed the ORG ’s decision . Referring to its findings of DATE , it held that the decision in the applicant ’s case was based on an unconstitutional provision which excluded that LAW ( GPE ) be applied in road - accident proceedings . Section CARDINAL of the Code of Administrative Offences provides that , if the extenuating circumstances outweigh the aggravating circumstances , the fine imposed may be reduced to the CARDINAL of the statutory minimum fine .

On DATE the ORG requested the applicant to submit information on his financial situation by DATE . It further noted that the issue would be assessed on the basis of the file if he failed to comply with this request . The applicant did not respond .

On DATE the ORG , sitting with the same single member as in the first round of the proceedings , partly allowed the applicant ’s appeal and , applying LAW , reduced the fine to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( ORG CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) . It confirmed its previous finding of DATE concerning the issue under LAW .

On DATE the applicant filed a complaint with ORG . He pointed out that the ORG had failed to hold a hearing and that the decisions had not been pronounced in public . Further , he complained that the composition of the ORG had been unlawful and challenged the member of the ORG for bias , who had already decided on his appeal in the first round of the proceedings .
On DATE the ORG submitted observations in reply .
On DATE the applicant supplemented his complaint .

On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint . It found that ORG had first to consider whether the applicant had caused death by negligence and only then whether or not he had done so in particularly dangerous circumstances , i.e. in a state of drunkenness . Neither the records of the hearings nor the reasons of the shortened version of the acquitting judgment of ORG disclosed any indication that the court had actually considered the applicant ’s drunkenness . Therefore , the administrative authorities were free to prosecute the applicant for the administrative offence of driving a car in a state of drunkenness , which did not infringe LAW No . CARDINAL .

As regards the lack of a public hearing before the ORG , ORG found that the applicant had failed to file a request to this effect in both the first and second set of the proceedings and that his appeal only related to issues of law .

As regards the lack of a public pronouncement of the ORG ’s decision , ORG , referring to LAW ( Allgemeines Verwaltungsverfahrensgesetz ) , found that this complaint did not raise an issue under the angle of LAW .

As regards the alleged bias of the member of the ORG , it found that the mere fact that the same ORG member had decided on the applicant ’s appeal in DATE set of the proceedings did not disclose any appearance of partiality . In conclusion , there was no indication of unfairness of the proceedings .
On DATE the applicant requested that the case be transferred to ORG ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof ) .
On DATE ORG allowed this request .
On DATE ORG ordered the applicant to supplement his complaint . The applicant did so on DATE .
On DATE the ORG submitted observations in reply , on which the applicant commented on DATE .

On DATE ORG declined to deal with the applicant ’s complaint pursuant to LAW of LAW ( Verwaltungsgerichtshofsgesetz ) since the amount of the penalty did not exceed ATS CARDINAL and no important legal problem was at stake as ORG had already dealt with the issue under LAW No . CARDINAL . This decision was served on the applicant ’s lawyer on DATE .

Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE provides that it is an offence for a person to drive a vehicle if the proportion of alcohol in his blood or breath is equal to , or higher than , QUANTITY or QUANTITY , respectively .
Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL LAW provides , so far as relevant at the material time , that :

“ ( CARDINAL ) It shall be an administrative offence ( Verwaltungsübertretung ) , punishable with a fine of not less than ATS CARDINAL,CARDINAL and not more than ATS CARDINAL,CARDINAL or , in default of payment with CARDINAL to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment , for any person :
( a ) to drive a vehicle when under the influence of drink ( ... )
( b ORG administrative offence is not committed where : ( ... )
( c ) facts constituting an offence under sub - sections ( CARDINAL ) , ( CARDINAL ) or ( CARDINAL ) also constitute an offence falling within the jurisdiction of the [ ordinary ] courts ... . ”

Under LAW of LAW , it is an offence , punishable by up to one years’ imprisonment , to cause death by negligence . Where the special circumstances of LAW § CARDINAL apply , the maximum possible sentence is increased to up to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .
Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL applies where a person commits the offence ,
“ after allowing himself , even if only negligently , to become intoxicated ( ... ) through the consumption of alcohol , but not to an extent which excludes ( ... ) responsibility ( ... ) ” .
Under an irrefutable presumption applied by the criminal courts , a driver with a level of blood alcohol of QUANTITY or higher is deemed to be “ intoxicated ” for the purposes of LAW § CARDINAL .
